title: 109_s56
content: The "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area and defines key terms such as Commission and Secretary. The Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado is established to conserve natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources along the Rio Grande River. Boundaries extend from the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge to the New Mexico State border, with a 1/4 mile buffer on each side. The Secretary will create a map and legal description of the area, with corrections allowed for minor errors. The Secretary may correct minor errors in the map and legal description of the Rio Grande Natural Area. The map and legal description will be available for public inspection at the Bureau of Land Management offices. Establishment of the Commission. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management, Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge, Colorado Division of Wildlife, Colorado Division of Water Resources, and Rio Grande Water. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various organizations. Members serve 5-year terms, can be reappointed, and serve without compensation. The Commission elects a chairperson. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission elects a chairperson and holds quarterly public meetings. The Commission receives technical assistance from the Secretary and other Federal agencies as needed. SEC. 5. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, meetings, and take testimony to carry out the Act. They can also enter into cooperative agreements with the State of Colorado or other entities to manage non-Federal land in the Natural Area. These agreements establish procedures for notifying the Commission of any actions that may impact the management plan. The Commission is authorized to assist the Secretary in implementing the management plan for the Natural Area by preserving and interpreting its resources. They may also help the State of Colorado in conserving State land and wildlife within the area. The Commission aims to increase public awareness and appreciation for the natural, historic, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources in the Natural Area. They also encourage land use policies consistent with the management plan and assist private landowners in implementing it. They also encourage land use policies consistent with the management plan and assist private landowners in implementing it. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary and the Commission, along with relevant agencies and private landowners, must prepare management plans for the Natural Area within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will handle Federal land management, while the Commission will manage non-Federal land and submit their plan to the Secretary for approval. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan submitted by the Commission for the Natural Area. If disapproved, the Secretary will take action accordingly. If the management plan for the Natural Area submitted by the Commission is disapproved, the Secretary must notify the Commission of the reasons for disapproval and allow them to submit revisions to the plan. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land. The management plans should consider existing Federal, State, and local plans to present a unified preservation, restoration, and conservation plan for the Natural Area. Plans for Federal land in the Natural Area must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act and be consistent with adjacent land management plans. The Secretary must publish management plans for the Natural Area in the Federal Register. The plans should include an inventory of resources, recommendations for resource management policies, and protection of natural values. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION OF NATURAL AREA. The Secretary administers the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws and the management plan, focusing on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources. Limited public recreation and scientific study are allowed, with a prohibition on water storage facilities. The management plan for the Natural Area focuses on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources. It includes reducing road use, prohibiting motorized vehicles, negotiating streamflow changes, and applying to private land within the area. The management plan for the Natural Area focuses on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources. Private land in the area is bound by the management plan if the landowner agrees in writing. Federal land in the Natural Area is withdrawn from various activities under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. The Secretary may acquire land in the Natural Area from willing sellers, which will be administered according to the management plan and this Act. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act does not apply to the Natural Area. SEC. 8 of the Act clarifies that it does not conflict with the Rio Grande Compact, regulate private land, impose streamflow requirements, create federal water rights, or impose stricter water quality standards. It also allows Colorado to acquire instream flow rights for environmental protection. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out the Act, and the Commission will terminate 10 years after the Act's enactment.
